item.title: Israel Gaza violence: US envoy arrives for de-escalation talks
item.description: Appeals to Israeli and Palestinian leaders for calm have so far failed to produce a ceasefire agreement.

item.title: Covid-19: Rate of Indian variant spread, and the future of the Tokyo Olympics
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Saturday morning.

item.title: Covid: Indian variant could disrupt 21 June easing, PM says
item.description: Second jabs for the over-50s and clinically vulnerable will be given sooner to ease concerns, PM says.

item.title: Teen girl found in boat drifting for three weeks at sea
item.description: Aicha, 17, was making the journey from Ivory Coast to Europe for the "chance of a better life".

item.title: China lands its Zhurong rover on Mars
item.description: The six-wheeled robot has made the hazardous descent to the surface of the Red Planet, China announces.

item.title: Last Debenhams stores close their doors
item.description: After 240 years of trading, Debenhams's remaining stores are welcoming customers for the last time.

item.title: UK troops seize IS weapons in Mali operation
item.description: A UK task force arrived in the West African country last year as part of a UN peacekeeping mission.

item.title: China uses Uyghur forced labour to make solar panels, says report
item.description: A report says 45% of the world's supply of a key panel component is obtained by a system of coercion.

item.title: PokÃ©mon card sales at major US retailer halted over security fears
item.description: A major US chain acts after a customer pulled a gun in a fight over the collectible trading cards.

item.title: White House vows probe into migrant children kept on buses
item.description: In at least one case a child was kept on a coach for four days, waiting to join his family.

item.title: Royal British Legion: Prince Charles marks charity's 100th birthday
item.description: Wreaths will be laid to honour the RBL, which was formed 100 years ago at 09:00 BST on Saturday.

item.title: The Papers: 'Threat to freedom' as PM warns of variant 'risk'
item.description: Boris Johnson's suggestion the Indian Covid variant could delay the easing of rules dominates the papers.

item.title: A lost whale - 6,000 miles from home
item.description: A grey whale called Wally is lost in the Mediterranean - far away from its home in the Pacific. Why?

item.title: Israel-Gaza: Strike collapses building during live BBC report
item.description: BBC producer Adnan Elbursh was broadcasting live from Gaza City when a building behind him was hit.

item.title: Experts warn extreme weather could cause 'climate trauma' pandemic
item.description: Mitzi says she has "climate trauma" because of the typhoons that have repeatedly flooded her home.

item.title: Liz Cheney: Why her sacking by the Republican Party matters
item.description: The BBC's Ros Atkins explains the decision to dismiss the congresswoman from her party leadership role.

item.title: Eurovision 2021: From child refugee to Swedish pop star
item.description: "It's a huge honour for me... It's like the biggest thank you I can give."

item.title: Cat jumps five storeys to safety from burning building
item.description: The daring feline leapt from a burning building in Chicago, Illinois, and landed on grass.

item.title: Week in pictures: 8 - 14 May 2021
item.description: A selection of powerful images taken around the world this week.

item.title: Covid lockdown easing: Why am I exhausted after socialising?
item.description: As our social lives go from 0 to 100, here's why some are feeling burned out after meeting friends.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Why doesn't Japan cancel the Games?
item.description: Current polls in Japan show nearly 70% of the population do not want the Olympics to go ahead.

item.title: Israeli-Palestinian conflict gives Biden foreign policy headache
item.description: The US president and his aides wish to avoid being drawn into this graveyard of US-led peace initiatives.

item.title: Drain-spotting: The people who keep their minds in the gutter
item.description: "Abstract flowers in an otherwise arid field": a world of artistry, history and surprising beauty.

item.title: TikTok: How Israeli-Palestinian conflict plays out on social media
item.description: As fighting escalates, the social network has become a platform for airing grievances.

item.title: Theatres in England get ready to reopen, but fear a Covid plot twist
item.description: Which shows are opening from Monday, will audiences return - and could the comeback be short-lived?

item.title: Is there a future for Alex Salmond?
item.description: The former Scottish first minister and SNP leader gambled on a breakaway new party and lost. Is this the end?

item.title: Lourdes: Pilgrims flock to French sanctuary online in their millions
item.description: With travel limited, millions are joining e-pilgrimages to a cave famed for its miraculous healings.

item.title: Chile indigenous: Time to make our voices heard
item.description: Members of indigenous groups in Chile will be represented in the constitutional convention.

item.title: 'We cannot sleep': Mothers caught in the Israel-Gaza conflict
item.description: Mothers in Israel and Gaza tell the BBC they are terrified for their families as fighting escalates.

item.title: Ferran Torres: Could Man City forward be replacement for Sergio Aguero up front?
item.description: The pursuit of a striker was expected to be a focus for Manchester City this summer, but do they already have the answer in Ferran Torres?

item.title: Feeling judged & an FA Cup dream - Schmeichel on his dad & Leicester's rise
item.description: Kasper Schmeichel tells Dion Dublin about growing up in football and why reaching the FA Cup final is a dream come true.

item.title: Mason Mount: 'I want to win trophies with Chelsea'
item.description: Chelsea midfielder Mason Mount says he wants to follow in the footsteps of club legends and win trophies.

item.title: Turkish GP cancelled and replaced by second race in Austria
item.description: The Turkish Grand Prix is cancelled just two weeks after it was put on the Formula 1 calendar and replaced by a second race in Austria.

item.title: Football, Racism & Social Media: 'I laughed because I knew abuse was coming'
item.description: BBC Sport speaks to Livingston captain Marvin Bartley as part of a new documentary, Football, Racism and Social Media.

item.title: Guardiola influence & teenager's deal with parents - meet Chelsea's Women's Champions League final opponents
item.description: Everything you need to know about Chelsea's Women's Champions League final opponents, including Pep Guardiola, the analyst turned hero, and a teenager's deal with her parents.

item.title: Erling Haaland and Jadon Sancho doubles win German Cup for Dortmund
item.description: Two goals each from Jadon Sancho and Erling Braut Haaland give Borussia Dortmund a 4-1 win over RB Leipzig in the German Cup final.

item.title: Covid-19: Five ways to make hugging safer, from the experts
item.description: Millions of people will be able to hug loved ones again from Monday. But can you minimise the risk?

item.title: What are the India, Brazil, South Africa and UK variants?
item.description: Concern is growing over a rise in UK coronavirus cases linked to a variant from India.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Lockdown restrictions have eased in England, Scotland and Wales

item.title: Which countries are on the green list for foreign holidays?
item.description: Foreign holidays are possible from 17 May, but there are still rules in place.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 38 and 39 in England are now being offered a Covid vaccine as the rollout continues.

item.title: Indian variant: What's causing the spike in Bolton?
item.description: The town has seen a sharp spike in Covid cases - driven by the emergence of the Indian variant.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 36 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid inquiry: What is it and how will it work?
item.description: An independent public inquiry has been announced, but how will it work?

item.title: Covid vaccine: Period changes could be a short-term side effect
item.description: Stories of genuine experiences shared online have been followed by a wave of anti-vaccine disinformation.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: What is a Covid passport and what are the plans for the NHS app?
item.description: People travelling abroad from England will be able to use the NHS app to prove their Covid vaccination status.

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.

item.title: Restaurants and pubs are reopening inside, but what are the rules?
item.description: People in England, Scotland and Wales will soon be able to drink inside a pub.

item.title: Covid: What refund rights are there for holidays abroad?
item.description: Quarantine-free overseas holidays will be possible after 17 May, but what rights do you have if plans or rules change?

item.title: Covid: What are the social distancing rules and the rule of six?
item.description: Guidance on hugging close friends and family is being relaxed in England and Scotland from 17 May.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Secondary school pupils in England will no longer be required to wear them in class from next week.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Thurrock: The place where people deal with their own rubbish
item.description: Residents are having to take their own waste to the collection vehicles to get rid of it.

item.title: Jeff Bezos and the secretive world of superyachts
item.description: The world's richest man will reportedly set sail next month on one of the largest superyachts ever built.

item.title: 'Talk to me': A train driver asking men to open up
item.description: A tragedy inspired Scotland's only woman freight train driver to get men talking about mental health.

item.title: Covid: YouTuber's 'miracle' survival after post-natal coma
item.description: Grace Victory says she was given a 5% chance of recovery after contracting Covid during pregnancy.

item.title: Friends reunion premiere date and celebrity guests announced
item.description: The much-anticipated special will see the original cast and celebrities reflect on the series.

item.title: Uyghur imams targeted in China's Xinjiang crackdown
item.description: China has targeted Muslim religious leaders, according to a new report, charging many with extremism.

item.title: Chinese dreams on Native American land: A tale of cannabis boom and bust
item.description: How the pandemic cannabis boom led to chaos on the Navajo Nation, pitting two minorities against each other.

item.title: The 'smart and cheeky' Aboriginal boy teaching Australia a lesson
item.description: A film about an Aboriginal boy's experience of school shines a light on Australia's failure to give all children a fair start.

item.title: Joe Ligon: America's 'longest juvenile lifer' on 68 years in prison
item.description: After waiting seven decades for freedom, Joe Ligon tells the BBC how he intends to spend the rest of his days.

item.title: Lelush: How a sulky Russian model became China's slacker icon
item.description: Getting trapped in a boy band reality TV contest was just the start of Lelush's unlikely journey.
